content.content: Robert Stone describes the troubleshooting techniques he used to reverse engineer a game to see if he could automate some of the boring parts of the game.

title: Gray-ish Hat Adventures In Automating Mobile Game Play: Why Tap When You Could Automate?
content:
Most mobile games are highly repetitive and require hours of "Grinding" which is the boring part of the game you have to do (or pay to bypass) in order to get stronger. In fact, this is the entire freemium business model and I'm willing to bet you have more then a few of these games installed on your phone.

Wouldn't it be great if you could figure out what the game was doing with each of these taps and automate it? Why stop there, you could create your own army and dominate the virtual landscape finally putting that college education to use!

Join us as we walk through just this process for a very popular mobile game that shall remain nameless (because I like the game and don't want to get banned!) but all shall be revealed at our next meeting. There will be a real-time walk through of:

  • Demo of the Game
  • Decompiling the app using JADX and JetBrains.dotPeek
  • Reverse engineering the API the game uses by way of BlueStacks, Charles, and ProxyCap.
  • Creating a WebSocket client ( using Moo as a change of pace from Moose ) to simulate what the app does, automating the boring grind-y parts of the game

If time permits a discussion on Moo versus Moose thoughts will be provided. Bring your mobile phones and your perlbrew, for we shall tear those meddling do-gooders asunder. Mwwwwwwhahahahaa!

content.content:
Todd Rinaldo has been working on the guts of Perl recently as part of the Perl compiler project at cPanel. He began with some of the pre-requisites needed to understand the presentation, including a basic understanding of C:

  • structures
  • unions
  • arrays
  • typedefs
  • #define
He showed Nicolas Rochelemagne's talk Introduction to Perl Internals to give some background. Nicolas covered some of the basics of Perl internal data structures and some information about how perl handles memory. After the video, Todd explained the B::C module and some of its siblings. He explained the difference between a stash and a pad, and talked about how new pads are added each time you add a scope. Todd spent a little more time discussing the internal data structures, mostly focusing on how they relate to stashes and pads. Next, he discussed how the parser doesn't actually generate an op-tree, as you might guess from an study of compilers. Instead, it generates several op-trees, that are linked together by entries in the stashes. He recommended spending time studying Reini Urban's Ill Guts if you are going to spend any time understanding this stuff. He spent some time discussing some of what cPanel is using the compiler for and what they hoped to accomplish. He discussed some ideas about optimizing op-trees. The talk generated several interesting discussions, that branched off the main topic at times.

content.content: Robert Stone delves into the cipher used by the Zodiac Killer in his newspaper announcements. He describes substitution ciphers and then shows how a homophonic substitution cipher fixes many of its problems. He ends by describing how the Zodiac Killer's cipher was solved.

title: Notes for 'Homophonic Substitution Cipher: Cracking the Code of a Killer' posted.

content: I've been doing some work with the Zodiac Killer's Z408 Cipher (I'm tons of fun at cocktail parties!) which is a Homophonic Substitution Cipher. Namely, creating a new Crypt::Z408 module and experimenting with a way to brute force generic Homophonic Substitution Ciphers which may or may not bear fruit. -- Robert Stone
title: Homophonic Substitution Ciphers - Cracking The Code of a Killer
